Good luck, Bruburn

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2011 08:36PM Bruburn wrote: Hi Mary, After a recent progression I have been struggling to feel positive.  When I was first diagnosed my pshychologist said that the best way to get through the day is to "just live".  Don't think about the future...this alleviates the depression of possibly not having a future and also reduces the pressure of "living every day like it is your last".   I understand that for you "just live" is also a problem because your life has changed so much. Mine has to.  So I set attainable goals and spend my time reinventing/rediscovering myself. I hope you find some peace soon. Hugs, B

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 06:48PM Bruburn wrote: Hi! Thank you for sharing this...we all need good news right now! I am also BRCA1+ and I've read that the PARPs are expected to be especially effective for us because our cancer cells already have one bad proofreading enzyme and the PARPs block another set of proofreading machinery.  You appear to be living proof of this! Hopefully the PARPs will continue to be developed for BRCA+ patients despite their recent poor results in broader trip neg studies. Best of Luck...be a miracle! Bruburn
Posts.Title: Encouraging PARP news nmiller1978 bottkota

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 10:46AM Bruburn wrote: Hi Windy, Sorry I missed this thread initially.  I'm glad you're feeling better.   I echo the anti-depressant thing...I went on them for the first time after diagnosis and they have helped take the edge off a lot.  So, if you hit a point where you think you need them, just get them.  Don't put too much thought into it.   Also, a story to laugh at (although it was horrible at the time...I laugh now at how ridiculous the situation was).  I was nursing when first diagnosed and had to emergency wean my son and start chemo. The emergency weaning brought on a period (my last period ever), while the chemo was in the process of slapping me into menopause.  So, at one point, I was still lactating, having a period and having hot flashes at the same time.  CRAZY! Anyway, you've got shoulders to lean on here...glad you're using them! Bruburn

Posts.Title: Crap - Brain Mets Bruburn china

Posts.Content: Bruburn wrote: Hi all, Once again I start with the disclaimer that although I do not post often (not much knowledge to share), I do check the boards daily and appreciate all of you so much. So, I've finished 7 treatments of dose dense AC.  It was supposed to be 8.  But, an echo showed minor changes in my heart so we decided to stop at 7.  Cat Scan shows no disease remaining in breast, nodes clear, bones stable and multiple small lesions stable on liver.  Onc says the spots on the liver may well be scar tissue.  Either way, the 3 liver spots I had that were in the range of 2cm are now tiny spots which are too small to measure.  All of the other small spots also shrunk in size.  I'm happy, but terrified at the same time. I am 5% ER+ and PR-.  So, we are going to try Femara and keep a close eye on things.  What's close?  Is three months reasonable for my next scan?  Should I push for one sooner? The onc has also suggested a mastectomy with NO node dissection.  She says there is a possible survival gain and it also reduces complications at "the end" when the cancer comes back.  She knows I want to fight and she says this is an option for fighting.  The surgeon said he would do it, but does not agree with the aggressive approach we are taking.  I think I'm up for the mastectomy...had a c-section last June and had no problems with recovery (and I was full of cancer!).  What do you think? Sorry this is so long... Best Wishes, Bruburn  liver, bone, brain mets.... Cancer is a ruthless enemy. But, God is able and I am worthy. I am up for the fight of/for my life. Dx 8/13/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 04:11AM - edited Sep 28, 2011 04:13AM by Bruburn As a mother of two small children, I am sending you hugs and a gentle pat on the back.  No mother, not even a healthy mother, gets everything right. You said it...you guys are okay.  Cancer has and will sadly continue to steal a lot of the extras...but you guys are okay.  THAT IS PRETTY AWESOME, GIVEN THE CIRCUMSTANCES.  YOU ARE AWESOME, DESPITE THE CIRCUMSTANCES.   When you were diagnosed, you could have gone to bed and never gotten up.  You could have quit fighting a long time ago.  You didn't.  You're awesome. Hugs, B PS: You've written beautifully what many of the mother's here are feeling I'm sure.  At least, it struck a chord with me...

Posts.Title: Olga Simkin Z"L leprechaun Bestbird

Posts.Content: Bruburn wrote: Hi, I have only posted a couple of times as I am still only 3 months since diagnosis.  I was Stage IV from the start, mets to bones and liver.  Liver lesions were "too numerous to count". After 4 rounds of Adriamycin and Cytoxin, my onc says there is regression in the liver.  She wouldn't give me specifics (like a %), but said it looked promising.  So, she is signing me up for four more rounds.  I asked about the taxanes, but she said if AC is working let's stick with it and get more regression...keep the taxanes for later. I was disappointed that she didn't provide more detail...I felt like she was trying to shield me from something...like maybe only 10% regression or something.  Anyway, I've decided that any regression is good and I should be thankful! I also wanted to post this as I know many Stage IV women don't get AC, so here is some good news for those who may be considering it. Thank you to all of you...this site has helped me so much.  I look forward to sharing more with all of you! Best, Bruburn  liver, bone, brain mets.... Cancer is a ruthless enemy. But, God is able and I am worthy. I am up for the fight of/for my life. Dx 8/13/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: Bruburn wrote: So I posted on Thursday that there was progression in my liver...I had been given a radiologist's report on my last abdominal ultrasound when I went to see my palliative doctor. The report from July simply says (re the liver) - "no evidence of metastatic disease". The October report says (re the liver) - <paraphrased because report it HORRIBLE> ...Multiple lesions are noted.  Of these there is a 1.5 cm nodular lesion in the left lobe suspicious of metastasis. There is a 1.1 cm hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe...A paragraph further down says the lesions are in the opposite lobes, so it was confusing. Also, this report had N/A under patient history!!!  Anyway, the palliative doc said that the take home message was the same...significant progression in the last three months.   So I finally spoke to my onc yesterday.  She sat down with a different radiologist  and they went though all of my scans together.  They have concluded that the lesion in the left lobe had been there since March and that it has been growing very slowly.  Since ultrasound isn't very sensitive, they cannot say whether or not it is really growing at all.  She would argue that this is actually stable disease.  Apparently the lesion on the right has also been there since March and has not changed and the second radiologist feels that it is not a met.  Apparently the radiologist from July agreed. So, she wants to wait six weeks and do a CT scan.  Her original proposal was to wait three months, but I said NO WAY.   So, I am in a weird limbo...happy if the second radiologist is right...wondering why none of these lesions were reported in July...guess I never was NED...confused as to how you can go from NED to significant progression to stable disease based on interpretation... I always knew radiologists didn't always agree etc...but this is freakin crazy.  I know this has happened to many women here...hugs to you and to all of us! Take home message ladies...just when I thought this cancer thing was as crazy as it could get, it just got crazier.   B PS: All this said, I am relieved and will enjoy my November and only think about this again when I have my CT results... :)  liver, bone, brain mets.... Cancer is a ruthless enemy. But, God is able and I am worthy. I am up for the fight of/for my life. Dx 8/13/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Wow, crazy limbo...crazy incompetence Bruburn justjudie

Posts.Title: Liver Done jleigh PizzaDad

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 08:51PM Bruburn wrote: I have no idea if my diet changes are helping.  I know that the regression I have seen thus far is due to 7 cycles of dose dense AC.  I am also making drastic diet changes because I am simply trying anything and everything I possibly can.  Not familiar with Block, but from day of diagnosis I cut out sugar and adopted an overall healthier, organic diet.  During chemo, I continued eating meats and dairy.  Now that chemo is over (we're trying Femara to stabilize remaining disease), I have cut out all dairy and meat.  My diet is high in fruits and veg (berries and citrus fruits, green and orange veg), whole grains and I take some supplements as well.   I have a family as well.  For dinner, I generally make a huge salad for everyone (although I eat most of it) and if I make a meat dish, I make another dish in parallel minus the meat for me.  To satisfy my sweet tooth I bake some favourites with whole wheat pastry flour,  stevia as the sweetner, unsweetened almond milk in place of milk etc.  Every morning I boil the kettle to make 1.5 litres of decaf green tea and put it in the fridge and drink this throughout the day. If you want to discuss further and/or trade ideas, PM me. Best, Bruburn

Posts.Content: Bruburn wrote: Hi Guys, Had a whole body CT on Mar 31.  Was very scared as this was the first scan of my head.   Got the results...no brain mets, no lung or lymph node mets, bone mets stable and liver has only 2 small lesions (one 3 mm and one 5 mm which had shrunk since last time)...my liver used to have too many lesions to count! I haven't had chemo since Dec 31...at that point I had many lesions which they thought were maybe scar tissue...so looks like they were and they resolved OR maybe Femara is working!   If Femara is working, it will be a small miracle since my pre-surgery pathology was 5% ER+ and PR- and post-surgery pathology was triple negative.  But if it is that would be sooooo sweeeet! I guess we'll see next time. For now, I am happy. Hugs to you all, Bruburn  liver, bone, brain mets.... Cancer is a ruthless enemy. But, God is able and I am worthy. I am up for the fight of/for my life. Dx 8/13/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
